user.biography: National Geographic Photographer, Explorer & Fellow / Marine Biologist

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Thomas Peschak in Tswalu Kalahari Reserve. May be an image of animal and nature.

node.text:
If Meerkats lived in the ocean they would probably be my favorite animal… BUT since they don’t swim, hunt fish or ride sharks they only come in 4th after marine iguanas, oar fish (look it up, I promise you won’t be disappointed) and salmon sharks. 

If meerkats are one of your favorite animals help me out with a funny caption for this pic. Suggestions in the comments please. 

Photographed on assignment for @natgeo in collaboration with @tswalufoundation #tswalu #kalahari #edgeofimpossible

node.text:
NEW BOOK 

Today I am excited to announce that my new book WILD SEAS published by @natgeo is available for pre-order. 

WILD SEAS spans more than 20 years of photography, 15 National Geographic Magazine assignments and many @saveourseasfoundation expeditions. For months I scoured my archive of more than a million images and, with great difficulty, selected my favorite 200 photographs that appear in this large format book. 

From playful grey whales plying the waters of Baja California to acrobatic manta rays in the Maldives and parading penguins in Antarctica, the book reveals both the splendor of vibrant seas and the dark side of overfishing, climate change and pollution. I try to make an impassioned case for revering and preserving the world’s oceans. 

WILD SEAS also charts my own transformation from marine biologist to National Geographic Photographer, revealing the rarely seen trials and tribulations behind the images and vividly recounting my adventures exploring some of the wildest ocean locales on our planet. 

WILD SEAS will be published by @natgeo on 5th October 2021 and I would be honored if you would pre-oder a copy from your favorite bookstore or online bookseller today. 

Thank You 🙏 

#WILDSEAS #WILDSEASBOOK #THOMASPESCHAKBOOK

node.text:
Some of the largest (up to 30 foot) and bulkiest whale sharks I ever encountered were in the Galápagos. Testimony to their giant dimensions are the 6 foot long silky sharks that use the whale shark’s rough sand paper like skin to brush off parasites. 

Which image in this gallery do you prefer, the first or the second?

Shot on assignment for @natgeo in collaboration with @parquegalapagos @charlesdarwinfoundation  @pelayosalinas 

#galapagos #whalesharks #sharks #pacific

node.text:
Spotted hyenas burst from their crates into a temporary holding pen. This clan is being released into the @Tswalu Kalahari Reserve to create a more balanced ecosystem. 

Despite their reputation, spotted hyenas are efficient hunters and without them and others predator, antelope can overgraze the more sensitive parts of an ecosystem. The fear of predation can increase the movement of antelopes, distributing grazing pressure more evenly across the reserve. 

With the climate becoming hotter and drier this is critical to prevent the reserve from succumbing to desertification. 

Shot on assignment for @natgeo working with @tswalufoundation and @keep 

Check out my new @natgeo story ‘The Edge of Survival’ in the August 2021 issue of National Geographic Magazine. 

#kalahari #hyenas #conservation #rewilding #climatechange #wild

node.text:
Pangolins are child’s play compared to trying to photograph this shy Kalahari creature, the Aardwolf! 

During almost 5 months in the @tswalu Kalahari Reserve I only had two encounters with this elusive animal, both lasting less less than 1 minute. Despite being a close relative of hyenas, the aardwolf feed only on insects. Using their long sticky tongue, a single animal can consume up to 250,000 termites per night. 

I savored each second in its presence and did what I could in such a short time to make the photograph as interesting as possible. Despite ending up not quite compelling enough to make it into the final selection for my @natgeo story, it nonetheless is a precious reminder of my time in the Kalahari. 

Shot on assignment for @natgeo with @tswalufoundation and @k.e.e.p_kalahari_project_

#kalahari #aardwolf #tswalu #photographer #southafrica #wildlifephotography #lightening

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Thomas Peschak in Tswalu Kalahari Reserve with @mr.thilon, @tswalu, @barry_peiser, @ottowhitehead, @wendz222, @tswalufoundation, and @aconservationstory. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Moths race across the night sky as a thunderstorm discharges lightening across the arid savannah landscape. More than 220 species of moth are found in the @Tswalu Kalahari Reserve and some take flight after the first rains soften the soils, releasing adults from their buried cocoons. 

This was NOT an easy photograph to make and for a long time I did not know how to bring this unusual scene to life. Finally, I decided on 5 second exposures to try to capture the lightening while my assistant @ottowhitehead using a powerful torch to light paint grasses and a small camethorn tree in the foreground. A head torch positioned right above the lens hood provided the illumination needed to capture the flight trails of the moths. We did this for about an hour until this image popped up on my LCD. 

At the same time  @aconservationstory from the @tswalufoundation kept watch so that I would not end up a snack to a curious lion. 

Shot on assignment for @natgeo working @tswalufoundation

Check out my new @natgeo story ‘The Edge of Survival’ in the August 2021 issue of National Geographic Magazine. 

#kalahari #moths #tswalu #photographer #southafrica #wildlifephotography #lightening

node.text:
Unpublished & Unseen 

For over a decade these photographs languished on a hard drive stored in a fireproof safe. Until earlier today when I had the sudden urge to share some unpublished nighttime whale shark images. Made in 2009 on assignment for @natgeo on expedition with the @saveourseasfoundation expedition in Djibouti. 

Personally I don’t think the images have dated too badly. What do you think? 

#whalesharks #ocean #sharks #djibouti #ocean

node.text:
Lioness vs. Giraffe 

A Kalahari lion chases a South African giraffe through a thicket of black thorn acacias magnificently draped in white spring flowers. The lioness was making a solo attempt and this healthy giraffe escape without so much as a scratch. Large predators are often the first animals to be lost in the wake of agriculture, ranching and development, but lions were reintroduced into the Tswalu Kalahari Reserve in 2001. Today two healthy and growing prides roam the eastern section of the reserve and exert an important influence on both the movement and behavior of browsers, grazers and smaller carnivores. 

Shot on assignment for @natgeo with @tswalufoundation. Check out my new @natgeo story ‘The Edge of Survival’ in the August 2021 issue of National Geographic Magazine. 

#kalahari #lions #tswalu #photographer #southafrica #wildlifephotography #giraffes

node.text:
What does it take to photograph a wild pangolin bathed in moonlight?

The answer is time, sweat and most importantly lots of help! For more than two months I worked with scientists @wendz222 and @valeryphaks roaming the vast vegetated dunes of the @tswalu Kalahari Reserve in pursuit of this photograph. 

When I started following Hercules, a large pangolin noted for its ability to rip open termite mounds with great ease, I stayed 50 feet away and used a long 500m lens. Two weeks later I was able to comfortably get within 30 feet, able to use shorter 300mm and 70-200 mm lenses. The first real breakthrough came when one afternoon Hercules made a beeline for me and sniffed my feet.  After a full month I was now photographing from just ten feet away using a 24-70 mm lens, but the image I had in mind required me to be closer. During this critical time I walked away from countless opportunities, as any wrong move could erase all the trust I had painstakingly gained. 

As the seasons shifted from winter to spring, Hercules changed routines, from being active during the day, to feeding exclusively at night. The time had come for me to make the photograph I had dreamed of for months.  Lying on my stomach, careful not to enrage horned adders, or impale myself on acacia thorns, I lay just a few feet away from Hercules. Finally able to make this intimate and evocative image of her foraging for ants with the light of a full moon illuminating the surrounding desert. 

Fortunately this reserve is remote, far from human habitation and incredibly well managed, including a formidable anti-poaching force. These ideal conditions make it possible for @wendz222 to safely habituate pangolins for science without putting them at risk from the illegal wildlife trade.

Shot on assignment for @natgeo with @tswalufoundation and @k.e.e.p_kalahari_project_ 

Check out my new @natgeo story ‘The Edge of Survival’ in the August 2021 issue.

node.text:
Hey... Hey... HEY... HEY !!! @natgeo photographer dude... you are looking the wrong way...I am right behind you!

Meerkats are expert diggers that excavate burrows with multiple entrances, some a fair distance apart from each other. Not only does this give them multiple escape options from predators, but also allows them to move underground stealthily without being detected... in this case by yours truly. 

Shot on assignment for @natgeo working with @tswalufoundation on the Tswalu Kalahari Reserve. Check out my new @natgeo story ‘The Edge of Survival’ in the August 2021 issue of National Geographic Magazine. 

#kalahari #meerkats #tswalu #photographer #sleepingonassignment #southafrica #itsbehindyou #wildlifephotography

node.text:
What am I doing in the Kalahari desert, 400 miles from the nearest ocean? Definitely no sharks or manta rays to photograph here! 

When the Covid-19 pandemic hit South Africa, I was all set to begin work on two new @natgeo magazine features taking me to far flung corners of the world. Instead the corona virus cancelled my international travel plans, forcing me to look for new stories to photograph closer to home. I live in the mountains, a few hours outside of Cape Town and “closer” ended up being a “just” two day drive to the north. 

During 2020 and 2021 I spent more than 4 months on assignment for @natgeo based at the Tswalu Kalahari Reserve working with @tswalufoundation to tell the story of the unique animals and plants that inhabit a extreme environment, where summer highs exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit and winter lows plummet to just 5 degrees. 

The story ‘Edge of Survival’ was published today in @natgeo magazine. My photography was wonderfully partnered with the evocative and masterful text of @science_scribe , a killer four page fold out illustration by @fernandog.baptista and kick a**s video by @ottowhitehead 

Most of my posts in the coming few weeks will focus on my time in the Kalahari desert, so I hope you love meerkats, pangolins, cheetahs and aardvarks as much as you do sea turtles, whales and seabirds.

node.text: There are few thing more wondrous than being in the presence of dancing and courting albatrosses. Unpublished photographs from my @natgeo story ‘Seabird Crisis’.
